name: SARS-CoV-2 Spike RBD
description: Design a protein that sticks to the coronavirus spike protein. This is the part of the virus that latches onto human cells.
mission: Design a protein that could help cure COVID-19 by blocking the virus from entering human cells.
pdbDescription: Crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 Spike RBD bound to human ACE2 receptor

E.name: Spike RBD
E.description: The viral 'key' that unlocks human cells - this is what you're designing a binder for

A.name: Human ACE2
A.description: The human cell's 'lock' that the virus exploits. Your binder should block this interaction

suggestedHotspots.label: ACE2 binding site
suggestedHotspots.description: Key residues that contact the ACE2 receptor. Targeting these blocks viral entry.

suggestedHotspots.label: Variant hotspots
suggestedHotspots.description: Residues commonly mutated in variants (E484K, N501Y). Consider for broad neutralization.

educationalContent:
## About SARS-CoV-2 Spike RBD

The [receptor-binding domain](gpt:RBD||What%20is%20the%20receptor-binding%20domain%20(RBD)%20of%20a%20virus%20and%20why%20is%20it%20important%20for%20infection?) (RBD) is like a "key" on the surface of the coronavirus. It fits into a "lock" on human cells called [ACE2](gpt:ACE2||What%20is%20ACE2%20and%20why%20does%20coronavirus%20target%20it?). When the key fits the lock, the virus can enter and infect the cell.

### Why is this a good target?
- It's essential for infection - block this, block the virus
- Scientists have studied it extensively, so we know a lot about it
- Many successful COVID treatments target this exact spot
- Great first challenge because it's well-understood

### What makes a good binder here?
Your designed protein needs to stick to the RBD tightly enough to prevent ACE2 from binding. Think of it like putting gum in a lock - the key can't fit anymore!

### Key residues
The virus uses specific amino acids (K417, Y453, L455, F486, Y505) to grab onto ACE2. These are good spots to target with your binder.

name: IL-6 (Interleukin-6)
description: Design a protein that grabs onto IL-6, a small signaling molecule that can cause harmful inflammation when overactive.
mission: Design a protein that could treat arthritis and other inflammatory diseases by calming down the immune system.

A.name: IL-6
A.description: The inflammatory messenger molecule - this is what you're designing a binder for

suggestedHotspots.label: Receptor site 1
suggestedHotspots.description: Residues that contact the IL-6 receptor alpha chain. Key for blocking signaling.

suggestedHotspots.label: Receptor site 2
suggestedHotspots.description: Residues that contact gp130, the signaling partner. Alternative blocking site.

educationalContent:
## About IL-6

[IL-6](gpt:IL-6||What%20is%20Interleukin-6%20(IL-6)%20and%20what%20role%20does%20it%20play%20in%20inflammation?%20Explain%20simply.) is a small protein that acts like a messenger in your immune system. When you're sick or injured, IL-6 tells your body to start inflammation - which is normally helpful for fighting infections.

### The problem
Sometimes IL-6 goes into overdrive:
- In [rheumatoid arthritis](gpt:rheumatoid%20arthritis||What%20is%20rheumatoid%20arthritis%20and%20how%20does%20inflammation%20cause%20joint%20damage?), it attacks healthy joints
- In severe COVID-19, it causes dangerous [cytokine storms](gpt:cytokine%20storm||What%20is%20a%20cytokine%20storm%20and%20why%20is%20it%20dangerous?)
- In some cancers, it helps tumors grow

### How your binder could help
By grabbing onto IL-6, your protein could prevent it from delivering its inflammatory message. It's like intercepting a letter before it reaches its destination.

### Real-world success
A drug called [tocilizumab](gpt:tocilizumab||What%20is%20tocilizumab%20and%20how%20does%20it%20work%20to%20reduce%20inflammation?) works exactly this way and has helped millions of patients!

name: VEGF-A
description: Design a protein that binds to VEGF-A, a growth factor that tells blood vessels to grow. Blocking it can starve tumors.
mission: Design a protein that could fight cancer by cutting off the blood supply that tumors need to grow.
pdbDescription: Crystal structure of Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) homodimer

A.name: VEGF-A (chain 1)
A.description: One half of the VEGF pair - design a binder for this growth factor

B.name: VEGF-A (chain 2)
B.description: The other half - VEGF works as a pair of identical proteins

educationalContent:
## About VEGF-A

[VEGF](gpt:VEGF||What%20is%20VEGF%20and%20how%20does%20it%20control%20blood%20vessel%20growth?%20Explain%20like%20I'm%20new%20to%20biology.) stands for Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor. It's the main signal that tells your body to grow new blood vessels - a process called [angiogenesis](gpt:angiogenesis||What%20is%20angiogenesis%20and%20why%20do%20tumors%20need%20it%20to%20grow?).

### Why block blood vessel growth?
Tumors are hungry - they need lots of blood to deliver nutrients and oxygen. Without new blood vessels, tumors can't grow larger than a tiny speck. By blocking VEGF, we can essentially "starve" the tumor.

### Real medicines that do this
- [Bevacizumab](gpt:bevacizumab||What%20is%20bevacizumab%20(Avastin)%20and%20how%20does%20it%20fight%20cancer?) (Avastin) - used for many cancers
- [Ranibizumab](gpt:ranibizumab||What%20is%20ranibizumab%20and%20how%20does%20it%20treat%20eye%20diseases?) (Lucentis) - treats eye diseases where unwanted blood vessels grow

### Design challenge
VEGF is a [dimer](gpt:protein%20dimer||What%20is%20a%20protein%20dimer?%20Explain%20simply.) - two identical proteins stuck together. Your binder could target either the receptor-binding site or try to break apart the pair.

name: TNF-alpha
description: Design a protein that neutralizes TNF-alpha, a powerful inflammation trigger involved in many autoimmune diseases.
mission: Design a protein that could treat Crohn's disease, psoriasis, and rheumatoid arthritis by blocking a key inflammation signal.
pdbDescription: Crystal structure of human Tumor Necrosis Factor alpha (TNF-alpha) trimer

A.name: TNF-alpha (chain 1)
A.description: One third of the TNF trimer - the target for your binder

C.name: TNF-alpha (chain 3)
C.description: Third chain - TNF works as a group of three

educationalContent:
## About TNF-alpha

[TNF-alpha](gpt:TNF-alpha||What%20is%20TNF-alpha%20and%20why%20is%20it%20called%20tumor%20necrosis%20factor?%20Explain%20simply.) (Tumor Necrosis Factor alpha) is one of the most important inflammation signals in your body. It was named because scientists discovered it could kill tumor cells, but it does much more than that.

### When TNF goes wrong
In autoimmune diseases, TNF-alpha attacks your own body:
- **Rheumatoid arthritis**: destroys joint tissue
- **Crohn's disease**: inflames the gut
- **Psoriasis**: causes skin to grow too fast
- **Ankylosing spondylitis**: fuses spine bones together

### Blockbuster drugs
TNF blockers are some of the most successful drugs ever made:
- [Humira](gpt:Humira||What%20is%20Humira%20(adalimumab)%20and%20how%20does%20it%20work?) (adalimumab) - was the world's best-selling drug
- [Remicade](gpt:Remicade||What%20is%20Remicade%20(infliximab)%20and%20what%20diseases%20does%20it%20treat?) (infliximab)
- [Enbrel](gpt:Enbrel||What%20is%20Enbrel%20(etanercept)%20and%20how%20is%20it%20different%20from%20other%20TNF%20blockers?) (etanercept)

### Structure note
TNF-alpha is a [trimer](gpt:protein%20trimer||What%20is%20a%20protein%20trimer%20and%20how%20is%20it%20different%20from%20a%20dimer?) - three identical proteins working together. This makes it an interesting target!

name: PD-L1
description: Design a protein that blocks PD-L1, which cancer cells use to hide from the immune system.
mission: Design a protein that could help the immune system find and destroy cancer cells that are hiding.

A.name: PD-L1
A.description: The 'invisibility cloak' protein that cancer cells use to hide - your target

educationalContent:
## About PD-L1

[PD-L1](gpt:PD-L1||What%20is%20PD-L1%20and%20how%20do%20cancer%20cells%20use%20it%20to%20avoid%20the%20immune%20system?%20Explain%20simply.) (Programmed Death-Ligand 1) is like an "invisibility cloak" for cells. When a cell displays PD-L1 on its surface, immune cells see it and think "this cell is friendly, don't attack."

### How cancer cheats
Cancer cells are sneaky - they cover themselves with PD-L1 even though they shouldn't. This tricks the immune system into leaving them alone, allowing the cancer to grow unchecked.

### Checkpoint inhibitors
Drugs that block PD-L1 are called [checkpoint inhibitors](gpt:checkpoint%20inhibitors||What%20are%20immune%20checkpoint%20inhibitors%20and%20how%20do%20they%20help%20fight%20cancer?). They "unmask" the cancer so immune cells can find and destroy it:
- [Keytruda](gpt:Keytruda||What%20is%20Keytruda%20(pembrolizumab)%20and%20what%20cancers%20does%20it%20treat?) (pembrolizumab)
- [Opdivo](gpt:Opdivo||What%20is%20Opdivo%20(nivolumab)%20and%20how%20does%20it%20work?)
- [Tecentriq](gpt:Tecentriq||What%20is%20Tecentriq%20(atezolizumab)%20and%20how%20is%20it%20used%20in%20cancer%20treatment?) (atezolizumab)

These have revolutionized cancer treatment and even cured some patients with advanced cancer!

### Your challenge
Design a protein that grabs PD-L1 and blocks it from sending its "don't attack me" signal.

name: HER2
description: Design a protein that targets HER2, a growth signal receptor that drives aggressive breast cancer.
mission: Design a protein that could treat breast cancer by blocking a signal that tells cancer cells to multiply.
pdbDescription: Crystal structure of HER2 extracellular domain

A.name: HER2
A.description: The growth signal receptor that drives aggressive breast cancer

educationalContent:
## About HER2

[HER2](gpt:HER2||What%20is%20HER2%20and%20why%20is%20it%20important%20in%20breast%20cancer?%20Explain%20simply.) (Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2) is a protein on the surface of cells that tells them to grow and divide. It's like a gas pedal for cell growth.

### The problem in cancer
About 20% of breast cancers have too many copies of HER2 - the gas pedal is stuck on full throttle. These "HER2-positive" cancers grow faster and are more aggressive.

### A success story
[Herceptin](gpt:Herceptin||What%20is%20Herceptin%20(trastuzumab)%20and%20how%20did%20it%20change%20breast%20cancer%20treatment?) (trastuzumab) was one of the first targeted cancer therapies. Before it existed, HER2-positive breast cancer was the most deadly type. Now, with Herceptin, patients have excellent outcomes.

### How HER2 drugs work
By binding to HER2, drugs can:
1. Block the growth signal
2. Mark cancer cells for immune destruction
3. Deliver toxic payloads directly to cancer cells (like [Kadcyla](gpt:Kadcyla||What%20is%20Kadcyla%20and%20how%20does%20it%20combine%20an%20antibody%20with%20chemotherapy?))

### Your challenge
This is a larger, more complex protein than the others. Can you design something that grabs onto its extracellular domain?

name: Insulin
description: Design a protein that binds to insulin. Understanding insulin binding is crucial for diabetes research.
mission: Design a protein that could help us understand diabetes by studying how insulin works in the body.

A.name: Insulin A chain
A.description: One of two chains that make up insulin - your target

B.name: Insulin B chain
B.description: The other insulin chain - they work together as a pair

educationalContent:
## About Insulin

[Insulin](gpt:insulin||What%20is%20insulin%20and%20how%20does%20it%20control%20blood%20sugar?%20Explain%20simply%20for%20someone%20new%20to%20biology.) is the hormone that tells your cells to absorb sugar from your blood. When you eat, your blood sugar rises, and your pancreas releases insulin to bring it back down.

### Why this matters
In [Type 1 diabetes](gpt:Type%201%20diabetes||What%20is%20Type%201%20diabetes%20and%20why%20can't%20these%20patients%20make%20insulin?), the immune system destroys insulin-producing cells. In [Type 2 diabetes](gpt:Type%202%20diabetes||What%20is%20Type%202%20diabetes%20and%20how%20is%20it%20different%20from%20Type%201?), cells stop responding to insulin properly.

### A tiny but mighty protein
Insulin is one of the smallest proteins that still folds into a complex 3D shape. It has two chains (A and B) held together by [disulfide bonds](gpt:disulfide%20bonds||What%20are%20disulfide%20bonds%20and%20why%20are%20they%20important%20for%20protein%20structure?).

### Historical significance
Insulin was the first protein to have its sequence determined (by Frederick Sanger in 1951) and one of the first to be made using genetic engineering. The discovery of insulin transformed diabetes from a death sentence to a manageable condition.

### Design challenge
Because insulin is so small, designing a binder that's specific to it (and doesn't accidentally bind similar proteins) is an interesting challenge!

name: Green Fluorescent Protein
description: Design a protein that binds to GFP, the famous glowing protein from jellyfish used throughout biology research.
mission: Design a protein that could help scientists build better research tools by binding to the most important protein in biology labs.
pdbDescription: Crystal structure of enhanced Green Fluorescent Protein (GFP)

A.name: GFP
A.description: The glowing jellyfish protein - design a binder for this important research tool

suggestedHotspots.label: Top of barrel
suggestedHotspots.description: Exposed loops at the top of the beta-barrel. Good surface for binder attachment.

suggestedHotspots.label: Side surface
suggestedHotspots.description: Accessible residues on the side of the barrel structure.

educationalContent:
## About Green Fluorescent Protein

[GFP](gpt:GFP||What%20is%20Green%20Fluorescent%20Protein%20and%20why%20did%20its%20discovery%20win%20a%20Nobel%20Prize?) is a protein from jellyfish that glows bright green under UV light. It might be the most important tool in modern biology!

### Why scientists love GFP
Scientists attach GFP to other proteins to track them inside living cells. Want to know where a protein goes? Make it glow! The 2008 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded for GFP's discovery and development.

### The beautiful barrel structure
GFP has a unique shape - an 11-stranded [beta-barrel](gpt:beta%20barrel||What%20is%20a%20beta%20barrel%20protein%20structure?%20Explain%20simply.) with the glowing part (chromophore) protected inside. This structure is so stable that GFP works even in harsh conditions.

### Rainbow of colors
Scientists have engineered GFP variants in almost every color:
- Blue (BFP)
- Cyan (CFP)
- Yellow (YFP)
- Red (from corals, like [mCherry](gpt:mCherry||What%20is%20mCherry%20and%20how%20is%20it%20related%20to%20GFP?))

### Design challenge
GFP is well-folded and stable, making it a nice beginner target. A GFP-binding protein could be useful for capturing or detecting GFP-tagged proteins in experiments!

name: Lysozyme
description: Design a protein that binds to lysozyme, a bacteria-killing enzyme found in tears, saliva, and egg whites.
mission: Design a protein that binds to one of the best-studied proteins in science - a classic challenge for protein engineers.
pdbDescription: Crystal structure of hen egg-white lysozyme

A.name: Lysozyme
A.description: The bacteria-destroying enzyme - a classic protein for binding experiments

suggestedHotspots.label: Active site cleft
suggestedHotspots.description: The groove where lysozyme binds and breaks bacterial cell walls.

suggestedHotspots.label: Backside surface
suggestedHotspots.description: Exposed surface away from the active site - good for non-inhibitory binders.

educationalContent:
## About Lysozyme

[Lysozyme](gpt:lysozyme||What%20is%20lysozyme%20and%20how%20does%20it%20kill%20bacteria?%20Explain%20simply.) is one of your body's natural antibiotics. It's found in tears, saliva, mucus, and breast milk, where it helps destroy bacteria by breaking apart their cell walls.

### A protein science classic
Lysozyme was:
- The first enzyme to have its 3D structure solved (1965)
- One of the first proteins used to study protein folding
- A favorite model protein for generations of scientists

### Why it's a great target
- Small (129 amino acids) and well-behaved
- Extremely stable
- Structure is known in incredible detail
- Lots of published data to compare your results against

### Fun fact
Egg whites are about 3.5% lysozyme - that's why eggs have some natural antibacterial properties! Alexander Fleming (who discovered penicillin) also discovered lysozyme.

### Design challenge
Can you design a protein that grabs onto lysozyme's surface? This is a classic test for protein design methods.

name: EGFR
description: Design a protein that binds to EGFR, a growth signal receptor involved in many cancers.
mission: Design a protein that could treat lung cancer and other cancers by blocking a key growth signal.
pdbDescription: Crystal structure of EGFR extracellular domain

A.name: EGFR
A.description: The growth signal receptor - a major cancer drug target

educationalContent:
## About EGFR

[EGFR](gpt:EGFR||What%20is%20EGFR%20and%20why%20is%20it%20important%20in%20cancer?%20Explain%20simply.) (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor) is a protein on the surface of cells that receives growth signals. When growth factors bind to EGFR, it tells the cell to divide.

### The cancer connection
Many cancers have EGFR problems:
- Too many EGFR receptors on the surface
- EGFR that's always "on" even without signals
- Mutations that make EGFR hyperactive

This is especially common in [non-small cell lung cancer](gpt:non-small%20cell%20lung%20cancer||What%20is%20non-small%20cell%20lung%20cancer%20and%20how%20is%20EGFR%20involved?).

### EGFR-targeting drugs
Two types of drugs target EGFR:
1. **Antibodies** that block the outside (like [Erbitux](gpt:Erbitux||What%20is%20Erbitux%20(cetuximab)%20and%20how%20does%20it%20block%20EGFR?))
2. **Small molecules** that block the inside (like [Tarceva](gpt:Tarceva||What%20is%20Tarceva%20(erlotinib)%20and%20how%20does%20it%20treat%20lung%20cancer?))

### Design challenge
EGFR is a larger, more complex target. The extracellular domain (outside the cell) has multiple regions - can you find a good spot for your binder to grab?

name: CD20
description: Design a protein that binds to CD20, a marker on B cells that's targeted in lymphoma and autoimmune diseases.
mission: Design a protein that could treat blood cancers and autoimmune diseases by targeting a specific type of immune cell.
pdbDescription: Structure of CD20 in complex with rituximab Fab

A.name: CD20
A.description: The B cell marker - targeted in lymphoma treatment

educationalContent:
## About CD20

[CD20](gpt:CD20||What%20is%20CD20%20and%20why%20is%20it%20a%20good%20target%20for%20treating%20blood%20cancers?%20Explain%20simply.) is a protein found on the surface of [B cells](gpt:B%20cells||What%20are%20B%20cells%20and%20what%20do%20they%20do%20in%20the%20immune%20system?), a type of white blood cell that makes antibodies.

### Why target CD20?
- It's found on almost all B cells (normal and cancerous)
- It's NOT on stem cells, so new healthy B cells can regrow
- It doesn't fall off the cell surface when antibodies bind
- It doesn't get internalized (stays targetable)

### Diseases treated by CD20-targeting drugs
- **[Lymphoma](gpt:lymphoma||What%20is%20lymphoma%20and%20how%20do%20CD20%20drugs%20treat%20it?)**: B cell cancers
- **[Leukemia](gpt:leukemia||What%20is%20leukemia%20and%20how%20is%20it%20different%20from%20lymphoma?)**: Blood cancers
- **Multiple sclerosis**: Autoimmune disease
- **Rheumatoid arthritis**: When B cells attack joints

### The first blockbuster antibody
[Rituximab](gpt:rituximab||What%20is%20rituximab%20(Rituxan)%20and%20how%20did%20it%20change%20cancer%20treatment?) (Rituxan) was approved in 1997 and showed that antibody therapies could successfully treat cancer. It's still widely used today!

### Design challenge
Design a protein that grabs CD20 on the cell surface. This could potentially mark B cells for destruction by the immune system.

name: PCSK9
description: Design a protein that blocks PCSK9, an enzyme that raises cholesterol levels in the blood.
mission: Design a protein that could dramatically lower cholesterol and prevent heart attacks.

A.name: PCSK9
A.description: The cholesterol-raising enzyme - blocking it dramatically lowers LDL

educationalContent:
## About PCSK9

[PCSK9](gpt:PCSK9||What%20is%20PCSK9%20and%20how%20does%20it%20affect%20cholesterol%20levels?%20Explain%20simply.) is an enzyme that controls how much "bad" [LDL cholesterol](gpt:LDL%20cholesterol||What%20is%20LDL%20cholesterol%20and%20why%20is%20it%20called%20bad%20cholesterol?) is in your blood.

### How PCSK9 works
Your liver has receptors that grab LDL cholesterol from the blood and destroy it. PCSK9 destroys these receptors, which means:
- More PCSK9 = fewer receptors = more cholesterol in blood
- Less PCSK9 = more receptors = less cholesterol in blood

### A genetic discovery
Scientists found that people born with PCSK9 mutations have:
- Those with low PCSK9: Very low cholesterol, 88% fewer heart attacks!
- Those with high PCSK9: Very high cholesterol, early heart disease

### PCSK9 inhibitor drugs
- [Repatha](gpt:Repatha||What%20is%20Repatha%20(evolocumab)%20and%20how%20does%20it%20lower%20cholesterol?) (evolocumab)
- [Praluent](gpt:Praluent||What%20is%20Praluent%20(alirocumab)%20and%20who%20should%20take%20it?) (alirocumab)

These can lower LDL cholesterol by 60% - even more than statins!

### Design challenge
Design a protein that grabs PCSK9 and prevents it from destroying LDL receptors. This could be a new approach to cholesterol-lowering therapy.

name: BDNF
description: Design a protein that binds to BDNF, a growth factor essential for brain health and memory.
mission: Design a protein that could help treat depression, Alzheimer's, or brain injuries by interacting with a key brain growth factor.
pdbDescription: Crystal structure of Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF)

A.name: BDNF
A.description: The brain growth factor - essential for neurons to survive and grow

educationalContent:
## About BDNF

[BDNF](gpt:BDNF||What%20is%20BDNF%20(Brain-Derived%20Neurotrophic%20Factor)%20and%20why%20is%20it%20important%20for%20brain%20health?%20Explain%20simply.) (Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor) is like fertilizer for your brain. It helps neurons survive, grow, and form new connections.

### Why BDNF matters
BDNF is involved in:
- **Memory formation**: Learning creates new neural connections
- **Mood regulation**: Low BDNF is linked to depression
- **Brain plasticity**: The ability to adapt and change
- **Neuroprotection**: Keeping neurons alive under stress

### BDNF and disease
Low BDNF levels are found in:
- [Depression](gpt:depression%20BDNF||How%20is%20BDNF%20related%20to%20depression?)
- [Alzheimer's disease](gpt:Alzheimer's%20BDNF||What%20role%20does%20BDNF%20play%20in%20Alzheimer's%20disease?)
- [Huntington's disease](gpt:Huntington's%20disease||What%20is%20Huntington's%20disease%20and%20why%20might%20BDNF%20help?)
- Age-related cognitive decline

### The challenge with BDNF as a drug
BDNF itself is hard to use as a medicine because it doesn't cross the [blood-brain barrier](gpt:blood-brain%20barrier||What%20is%20the%20blood-brain%20barrier%20and%20why%20does%20it%20matter%20for%20brain%20drugs?). New approaches are needed!

### Design challenge
Design a protein that interacts with BDNF. This could help us understand BDNF biology or lead to new research tools for studying brain function.
